title: 3D meshes disappear shortly after initial load (particles remain)
description:
## Summary
On initial page load (without any manual scrolling), all *mesh* objects (FloatingShapes, PrismCenterpiece, debug cube when enabled) briefly render then disappear after ~0.5‚Äì0.75s. Instanced particle points continue to render.

## Current Behavior
- Meshes visible for a short time after load, then vanish.
- Particles/points continue rendering.
- This happens even when the user does not scroll.

## Expected
Meshes should remain visible at rest on the hero section.

## Troubleshooting / Changes Tried
- Removed `drei` `ScrollControls` usage (we‚Äôre using GSAP/native scroll) and removed `useScroll()` fallback in `Hero3D`.
- Hardened `useGSAPScroll` to avoid killing other ScrollTriggers on cleanup and to ignore tiny initial `scrollY` values.
- Changed particle materials to additive + `depthWrite={false}` so instanced particles can‚Äôt occlude meshes.
- Added defensive guard in postprocessing so `EffectComposer` doesn‚Äôt crash on null GL context attributes.
- Adjusted `FloatingShapes` scroll-driven fade/positioning:
  - clamp tiny initial scroll to 0
  - reduce z-shift and fade aggressiveness
  - set `depthWrite={false}` on shape material

## Notes / Related Console Noise
- Manifest referenced missing `/icon-192.png` and `/icon-512.png`; updated `public/site.webmanifest` to use `/icon.svg` to remove the console warning.

## Relevant Commits
- `73d0c9e` Fix 3D mesh occlusion and GSAP cleanup
- `0fcb648` Guard postprocessing init and stabilize CTA particles
- `5041dee` Remove ScrollControls and stabilize initial scroll
- `fdb3550` Prevent initial-load shape fade-out

## Hypotheses
- Something is changing camera/frustum/culling state after initial mount (meshes culled, points still visible).
- Depth/transparency ordering still problematic for some GPU/driver combos.
- Context state changes after suspense/environment load causing materials/shaders to fail silently.

## Next Debug Steps
- Temporarily set `frustumCulled={false}` on key meshes (FloatingShapes meshes + prism) and confirm if they still disappear.
- Log `state.camera` (near/far/position), and per-mesh `matrixWorld` validity (NaN checks) around the time they vanish.
- Temporarily disable `Environment` + `MeshTransmissionMaterial` and verify if only ‚Äústandard‚Äù materials still vanish.
- Add a simple always-visible `meshBasicMaterial` cube in `Scene` to confirm whether *all* meshes vanish or only specific materials.
close_reason: Meshes stay visible at rest after clamping scroll inputs and disabling culling on hero meshes; added fallback material for low/WebGL1 devices.

title: Fix 3D shapes disappearing on load - Environment map race condition
description:
3D FloatingShapes appear on page load but disappear after ~500-750ms when the Environment HDR texture finishes loading.

## Root Cause
The `<Environment preset="night" />` component combined with `<Preload all />` causes a race condition. When the HDR environment texture loads, it gets applied to `meshPhysicalMaterial` surfaces incorrectly, making them invisible.

## Why particles stay visible
Particles use pointsMaterial/meshBasicMaterial which do not use environment maps.

## Fix
Add `envMapIntensity={0}` to the meshPhysicalMaterial in FloatingShapes.tsx to prevent it from using the scene environment.
notes:
## Retro
- Fix was straightforward - one-line change adding envMapIntensity={0}
- The issue description and worker prompt were clear and accurate
- Verified: build passes, no console errors, page displays correctly after 4+ seconds
close_reason: Fixed: Root cause was two-fold: (1) Loader/ContentFade components using useProgress not handling the case when no assets need loading - added detection for total=0 to skip waiting. (2) Opaque body background (bg-background) was covering the fixed Canvas - removed from body and made Hero section transparent to let 3D show through.

## Implementation Guide: Add Interactive Hover Effects on 3D Elements

### Objective
Implement raycasting-based hover detection on 3D elements (FloatingShapes and PrismCenterpiece) with smooth visual feedback.

### Key Files to Modify
1. **src/components/canvas/FloatingShapes.tsx** - Add raycasting and hover state to FloatingShape component
2. **src/components/canvas/PrismCenterpiece.tsx** - Add raycasting and hover state to prism mesh

### Implementation Approach

#### 1. Add Raycasting Infrastructure (Both Components)
- Import useThree hook to access raycaster: `import { useThree } from "@react-three/fiber"`
- Store hover state in refs to avoid re-renders
- Use useFrame to perform raycasting each frame
- Pattern:
  ```typescript
  const raycaster = useRef(new THREE.Raycaster());
  const hoverState = useRef(false);
  
  useFrame((state) => {
    raycaster.current.setFromCamera(state.mouse, state.camera);
    const intersects = raycaster.current.intersectObject(meshRef.current);
    hoverState.current = intersects.length > 0;
  });
  ```

#### 2. Hover Visual Effects (FloatingShapes)
- Scale: Lerp to 1.15x when hovering, back to 1.0x when not
- Emissive intensity: Increase from 0.8 to 1.2 on hover
- Material opacity: Keep opacity smooth during transitions
- Cursor: Change to pointer when hovering

#### 3. Hover Visual Effects (PrismCenterpiece)
- Scale: Subtle increase to 1.1x on hover
- Rotation speed: Slightly increase rotation intensity during hover
- Emission: Increase material brightness/emissiveIntensity
- Add subtle glow increase

#### 4. Cursor Management (Use drei useCursor)
- Import: `import { useCursor } from "@react-three/drei"`
- Call `useCursor(hoverState.current)` in both components
- Handles cursor changes automatically

#### 5. Performance Considerations
- Raycasting is done once per frame in useFrame - efficient
- Use refs for hover state to avoid re-renders
- Smooth lerp transitions (0.1-0.15 factor) for visual polish
- Test on mobile: ensure raycasting doesn't cause jank

### Acceptance Criteria
- FloatingShapes respond to mouse hover with scale and emissive changes
- PrismCenterpiece responds to mouse hover with subtle scale/brightness increase
- Cursor changes to pointer when hovering over interactive elements
- Transitions are smooth using lerp interpolation
- Works with both mouse and touch interactions
- No performance regression on mobile devices
- Visual feedback is subtle but clearly noticeable

### Testing Checklist
- Desktop: Hover over floating shapes, see scale and glow change
- Desktop: Hover over central prism, see response
- Mobile/tablet: Touch elements, confirm feedback works
- Performance: Check DevTools performance tab for jank
- Gates: Run visual-qa and codex-review after implementation

### Reference Implementation
Both components already use useFrame and have mesh refs. Add raycasting logic alongside existing animation logic. Keep state in refs, apply lerping to material properties (scale, emissive, opacity).

### Notes
- Use THREE.Raycaster from three.js (already imported in both files)
- Keep hover effects subtle - avoid excessive scale changes (max 1.1-1.15x)
- Consider mobile: raycasting works on touch but may feel different than mouse
- Sync with existing animation patterns (useFrame, lerp, smooth transitions)

## Worker Prompt: Add Parallax Depth Effect to Cards

### Objective
Implement a mouse-responsive parallax 3D tilt effect on FeatureCard components. Cards should subtly tilt based on mouse position, creating a depth perception illusion with matching shadow shifts.

### Key Files to Modify
- **src/components/sections/FeatureCard.tsx** - Add parallax hook and tilt transform logic
- **src/components/sections/Features.tsx** - Set up mouse tracking context for cards container
- Consider creating a reusable hook: **src/hooks/useCardParallax.ts** - Centralize mouse parallax logic

### Implementation Approach

#### 1. Mouse Tracking (Features.tsx)
- Add useEffect to track mouse position globally on the cards container
- Store normalized mouse position (-1 to 1 range) in a ref or context
- Update on mousemove and reset on mouseleave

#### 2. Parallax Hook Pattern (FloatingShapes.tsx reference)
Look at `FloatingShapes.tsx` (lines 44-47) for the mouse parallax pattern:
```
const parallaxStrength = 0.3 + index * 0.1;  // Varies by card position
const targetX = initialPos.x - mouse.x * parallaxStrength;
const targetY = initialPos.y - mouse.y * parallaxStrength * 0.5;
```

#### 3. Card Transform (FeatureCard.tsx)
- Calculate rotateX/rotateY based on mouse offset relative to card bounds
- Apply perspective via parent container
- Use CSS transforms with smooth transitions (~300-500ms)
- Limit rotation to ~5-10 degrees max

#### 4. Shadow Enhancement
- Adjust shadow blur/offset based on tilt angle
- Darker shadow when tilted forward (higher rotateX)
- Creates illusion that card is floating above surface

#### 5. Touch Device Handling
- Disable parallax on touch devices (check via pointer-events or device detection)
- Prevent janky movement on mobile

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Cards tilt smoothly based on mouse position
- [ ] Tilt effect is subtle (max ~8-10 degrees rotation)
- [ ] Shadow deepens/shifts with tilt to enhance depth illusion
- [ ] Effect resets smoothly on mouse leave

- [ ] Disabled on touch devices

## Worker Prompt: Add Advanced Post-Processing Effects

### Objective
Enhance the visual richness of the 3D scene by implementing advanced post-processing effects using @react-three/postprocessing. The implementation should be performance-aware, configurable, and respect accessibility constraints.

### Key Files
- **Primary file to modify:** `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/components/canvas/Effects.tsx`
- **Reference file:** `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/components/canvas/Scene.tsx`
- **Device detection:** `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/hooks/useDeviceDetection.ts`

### Current State
The Effects component currently implements:
- Bloom effect (adaptive intensity based on GPU tier)
- Vignette effect for depth
- GPU tier-aware rendering with EffectComposer already configured

### Implementation Approach

**1. Add New Effects to Effects.tsx**

Implement these effects in order of priority:

**Chromatic Aberration** (design requirement)
- Import `ChromaticAberration` from @react-three/postprocessing
- Set subtle offset on edges: start with offset of ~0.003-0.005
- Make it configurable via device.gpu tier
- Disable on mobile/low-end devices for performance

**Film Grain / Noise** (design requirement)
- Import `Noise` from @react-three/postprocessing
- Add subtle grain overlay: start with opacity ~0.15
- Ensure it enhances without overpowering content
- Scale down intensity on mobile devices

**Color Grading** (design requirement)
- Use `HueSaturation` effect to enhance purples and cyans
- Adjust saturation selectively (~+10-20%)
- Use `BrightnessContrast` if needed for fine-tuning
- High-end only; disable on mobile

**Scanline Effect** (optional/design nice-to-have)
- Import `ScanlineEffect` from @react-three/postprocessing
- For retro-tech feel on desktop only
- Keep opacity low (~0.1-0.15) to avoid distraction

**2. Performance & Accessibility**
- Adaptive quality:
  - High GPU: All effects enabled with full intensity
  - Medium GPU: Core effects (bloom, vignette, noise, grain) only
  - Low GPU: Bloom + vignette only (maintain current behavior)
- Mobile: Disable chromatic aberration, color grading, scanlines; reduce grain intensity
- Maintain 50+ fps target (monitor in PerformanceStats if available)

**3. Configuration Pattern**
```typescript
// Example effect parameter pattern
const effectParams = {
  chromaticAberration: device.gpu === "high" ? 0.004 : 0,
  noiseIntensity: device.gpu === "high" ? 0.15 : 0.1,
  // ... etc
};
```

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Chromatic aberration visible and subtle on edges
- [ ] Film grain/noise adds texture without overpowering content
- [ ] Color grading enhances purples and cyans naturally
- [ ] All effects disabled/scaled on mobile and low-end devices
- [ ] Performance remains 50+ fps on target devices (verify with PerformanceStats)
- [ ] Effects can be toggled/disabled for accessibility (via device.gpu detection)
- [ ] No visual artifacts or flickering
- [ ] Code is well-commented with effect parameters documented
- [ ] Scanline effect optional but implemented if time allows

### Testing Checklist
- Desktop (high GPU): All effects visible and blended naturally
- Tablet (medium GPU): Core effects present, no jarring absences
- Mobile: No chromatic aberration, reduced grain, clean performance
- Low-end device: Fallback to bloom + vignette only
- Check console for WebGL errors
- Verify 60 fps maintained with Chrome DevTools Performance tab

### Notes
- The EffectComposer is already set up with multisampling=0 and stencilBuffer=false for performance
- Device capabilities passed via `device` prop already includes GPU tier detection
- Effects blend order matters - order them for best visual result (typically: vignette ‚Üí bloom ‚Üí grain ‚Üí chromatic ‚Üí color grading)
- Refer to @react-three/postprocessing docs for BlendFunction modes (ADD, NORMAL, SCREEN, etc.)

## Worker Prompt: Add Orbital Rings or DNA Helix to Testimonials Background

### Objective
Enhance the TestimonialsScene background with either orbital rings or DNA helix particle formations. The current scene uses three distorted spheres - we need to add a more visually interesting geometric structure while maintaining performance and not distracting from testimonial content.

### Key Files
- **Main file**: `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/components/canvas/TestimonialsScene.tsx` - Background 3D scene
- **Reference file**: `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/components/canvas/FeaturesParticles.tsx` - Contains proven helix formation code (lines 56-65)
- **Usage**: Testimonials section component at `/home/marci/projects/prism-digital/src/components/sections/Testimonials.tsx`

### Implementation Approach

**Option 1: Adapt Existing Helix (Recommended)**
- Reference the double-helix spiral code from FeaturesParticles (formation 3, lines 56-65)
- Create a simpler particle system with ~500-800 particles (vs 2000 for features)
- Use similar DNA spiral parameters: 3-4 turns, 8-12 unit height, 2-3 unit radius
- Maintain two strands offset by 180 degrees
- Use purple/cyan palette (matches theme)
- Add subtle pulsing glow via brightness modulation

**Option 2: Orbital Rings**
- Create concentric circular rings at different rotation speeds
- Rings orbit around the existing sphere group
- 3-4 rings with varying radii (8, 10, 12 units)
- Glowing line renderer or instanced torus geometries
- Slow rotation synchronized to scroll (already in groupRef)

### Implementation Details

1. **Add particle system component** (recommended: helix)
   - Create as a child group within the existing group
   - Use THREE.Points or InstancedMesh for performance
   - Keep particle count low for testimonials section

2. **Animation properties**
   - Rotation: sync to existing scrollProgress (already computed)
   - Pulsing: subtle brightness modulation (0.7-1.0 range)
   - Position: centered in the group, doesn't need individual bob
   - Slight bobbing optional: use sine/cosine with low amplitude

3. **Visual styling**
   - Colors: blend purple (#a855f7), cyan (#22d3ee), pink (#f472b6)
   - Opacity: 0.2-0.4 so it doesn't compete with content
   - Blending: AdditiveBlending for glow effect
   - Glow effect: can use PointsMaterial with sizeAttenuation

4. **Performance considerations**
   - Testimonials section has reduced scroll range vs features
   - Keep particle budget reasonable (~500-1000 particles)
   - Use AdditiveBlending (single pass, lower cost than many materials)
   - No need for distortion materials - simple positions are faster

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Orbital rings OR helix structure is visible in Testimonials section
- [ ] Animation is smooth (no jank during scroll)
- [ ] Doesn't distract from testimonial cards or text readability
- [ ] Integrates cleanly with existing three distorted spheres
- [ ] Responsive: works on mobile (can reduce particle count)
- [ ] Follows existing code patterns (useRef, useFrame, cleanup)
- [ ] Resource cleanup on unmount (dispose geometries/materials)
- [ ] Passes visual-qa and codex-review gates

### Notes
- FeaturesParticles is a great reference: it shows helix + particle system patterns
- Keep scroll responsiveness: the helix/rings should rotate or pulse with scrollProgress
- Test performance on low-end devices
- Ensure no WebGL errors in console
